direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This material is the sole property of the Walt Disney Company and is restricted to the use of the Walt Disney Company and its authorized employees and agents. Distribution, disclosure, reproduction or sale of this material to unauthorized personnel is strictly prohibited. January 5, 1993 THE THREE MUSKETEERS OPEN ON: 1   EXT. GASCONY - DAWN                                        1 Dawn. A verdant field in Gascony. BIRDS CALL from tree- tops. The WIND RUSTLES through green leaves. A fox darts into a thick hedge. And last, anti-pastoral, out of place -- the sound of CLASHING STEEL. SUPERIMPOSE:   France, 1625. Suddenly, two young men burst INTO VIEW, sword points cutting brilliant arcs through the morning air. The first is GIRARD, bearded, nearly thirty, a man in every facet. The second, D'ARTAGNAN. Younger in appearance and attitude. Exuberant, handsome. And at just this moment, bounding over a low stone wall with a boisterous cry. They battle across an expanse of turf thick with dew. Girard is the more polished combatant. But d'Artagnan is nearly a force of nature. He whips his sword through the air with wild-hearted abandon. He tumbles and somer- saults. This is fun. Girard and d'Artagnan cross the field, pass over a wooden fence, struggle toward a stable and hayloft. As they fight, both men utilize a variety of props. Handfuls of hay, a wooden spar, quick kicks from heavy boots. Anything goes as the swords cut through the air. D'Artagnan, gaining increasing advantage, forces Girard up against a peaceful country manor. Girard, seemingly cornered, executes a gymnastic flip onto the roof, fights from this high angle. D'Artagnan merely smiles... and follows. 2   ANGLE ON ROOFTOP                                           2 Seen briefly in silhouette against the rising sun, Girard and d'Artagnan scramble up the v-shaped rooftop, pause to exchange swipes at the peak, then slide down the other side, attacking, defending, as they go. 3   INCLUDE INTERIOR                                           3 Inside the manor house, a HANDSOME WOMAN of forty glances up from her writing table, hears FOOTSTEPS on the roof. She reacts -- curious, not afraid -- and steps to an open window. As  if to follow the footsteps to the other side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 4   BACK TO SCENE                                              4 Girard leaps to the ground first -- landing in an en- closure filled with SQUAWKING GEESE. D'Artagnan flies after. The geese scatter, d'Artagnan -- whose wild progress frequently resembles that of a young colt -- stumbles briefly. Girard seeks advantage, thrusts his sword toward the young man's heart. But d'Artagnan parries the blow with a heavy gloved hand, rolls over the offending goose -- glances deadpan apology -- and rises to fight again. The epic battle continues. Girard's modest success de- volves into desperate flight. D'Artagnan's seemingly endless reserves are wearing him down. Then, at the last possible moment, Girard spies escape: a slow- moving HAYCART RUIMBLING up the country road. He runs toward the cart, leaps upon it, turns back to d'Artagnan with a confident smirk -- an expression that vanishes when the young Gascon executes a nearly impossible leap to join him. And still they battle, the clash of swords a kind of music by now, the men, their exuberance, the bright morn- ing all combined into a dazzlingly heroic display. Just then: The haycart crosses a wooden plank bridge. Girard backs from d'Artagnan's sword, weak from exhaustion, he stumbles. D'Artagnan has his man and he knows it. He prepares one last blow -- -- And the haycart shifts, deposits both men over the side and down to the small muddy creek below. A comical antidote to all this glorious swordplay. 5   INCLUDE CREEK                                              5 Girard lands flat on his back, stunned, his sword out of reach. D'Artagnan lands similarly, but recovers with grace, or rather, as much grace as the muddy situation will allow. He rolls toward Girard, sword in hand, and lightly places the sharp gleaming tip against his adam's apple. A long beat. Then a surprise. Girard begins to laugh, long and loud. D'Artagnan responds with a charmed smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Had enough?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe now would be a good time to end your, uhm, formal training. Well done. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 5   CONTINUED:                                                    5 D'ARTAGNAN Thank you, sir. D'Artagnan leaps to his feet, races off without another word. Girard struggles upward, peers at the shape of his clothing -- cut to ribbons, muddy and soaked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And god have mercy on whomever you meet next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 6   EXT. GASCONY - HANDSOME WOMAN'S POV - DAY                     6 D'Artagnan races across the green fields, triumphant. 7   ANOTHER ANGLE                                                 7 She stands at the open window, watches his coltish high steps with love. Sadness too. CUT TO: 8   INT. D'ARTAGNAN'S HOME - DAY                                  8 D'Artagnan steps through the country manor, calls out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother...? But he does not see her.    D'Artagnan continues, chatter- ing proudly as he goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you see us? You heard us, I'll bet. Girard finally surrendered a compliment... though I almost had to kill him to get it... Mother...? D'Artagnan comes upon an open door, a small room beyond. He pauses, then steps inside. 9   INCLUDE FATHER'S STUDY                                        9 A Spartan interior. Heraldic emblems upon the wall, sou- venirs from battles won and lost. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 9   CONTINUED:                                                    9 A piece of parchment, on it the words: "All For One, and One For All." And, in a place of honor, a worn blue and gold tunic. Below it, the Handsome Woman, d'Artagnan's mother, kneels at an open chest. She turns back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you hear me? Girard -- MOTHER Sit. D'Artagnan sighs, sits in a large wooden chair. A beat. His mother speaks quietly, eyes turned back to the open chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father was a proud man. And he had a right to be. I never knew one as brave or as kind. He knew that his strength was a gift to be given in the service of honor. That is why he dedicated his life to his country and his King. That is why he gave his life, for both. She reaches into the chest, carefully extracts a beautiful saber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I watched you this morning and saw someone I knew. You have your father's heart, his will to fight, his courage. But these gifts have no value unless they are given. She rises, holds the sword out to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's time for you find your fortune with men as brave and as bold as you are. In Paris. With the King's Musketeers. (re: sword) You'll need this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father's sword. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 9    CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forged in the Crusades, handed from generation to generation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now to me. D'Artagnan can't help it, his eager reply leavens the nobility of the moment with warm humor, youthful inno- cence. His mother smiles as she repeats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, son.   And now to you. With that, she holds out the beautiful saber.         D'Artagnan takes it firmly into his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 10   EXT. GASCONY - DAY                                               10 A huge and beautiful field appropriate to the moment. Mother and son stand in the vast expanse. D'Artagnan holds a restless horse by the reins, his traveling satch- el attached to the saddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not your mother now. I'm speaking for your father. And this is what he would have told you. Never forget the code of the d'Artagnans. It is your special heritage. (beat) Always seek out adventure...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never run from a fight...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never submit to insults.    Except from the King.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 10   CONTINUED:                                                       10 MOTHER And be wary of Cardinal Richelieu for he rules France through the King. A bittersweet moment. D'Artagnan posed before his first great adventure. But not completely certain that he wishes to leave home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother. Maybe I should wait. Until after harvest. D'Artganan's mother smiles, understands.       And speaks gently to urge him forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've heard that every man in the Musketeers is on the run from someone or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.   But what am I running from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shrew of a mother, and a drafty old house. Now go. And in this fashion, she releases him. D'Artagnan sweeps his Mother into an embrace, now turns, heroic, and leaps into the saddle. The horse reacts with a start, skitters in a half-cicle. D'Artagnan struggles to gain control, finally brings the horse to rein. He manages a charmed grin. His mother smiles, scolds:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And for heaven's sake, practice your horsemanship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Horsemanship.    Got it. D'Artagnan digs his heels into the horse's flanks, shoots off across bright green fields. His Mother shields her eyes from the sun, feels a gathering of tears, and watches him ride into the distance. 11   HIGH ANGLE                                                       11 D'Artagnan's flight toward a new world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 7. 12   EMBLEM OF KING'S MUSKETEERS                                  12 It FILLS the SCREEN, serves as background for the MAIN TITLES. As the FINAL CREDIT APPEARS, and the MUSIC ENDS, the blade of a sword ENTERS FRAME. It slides beneath the emblem, pries it off the wall. The emblem falls to the floor with an undignified thud. A fire blazes in a huge hearth behind it. 13   INCLUDE MUSKETEERS' HEADQUARTERS                             13 A room in the Musketeers Headquarters. The fallen emblem is retrieved by JUSSAC, an officer who wears the bright red tunic of the Cardinal's Guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I do with this? Jussac offers   the emblem to a tall, elegant wraith in black finery,   a patch covers one eye. This is the COUNT DE ROCHEFORT,   Richelieu's right hand, one of the deadli- est swordsmen   in all of France.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throw it on the fire with everything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But this is the emblem of the Musketeers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Musketeers no longer exist. Or haven't you heard? (cold command) Throw it on the fire. Jussac hastily adds the emblem to the fiery blaze, it is instantly consumed. Rochefort watches it burn, then walks to a balcony overlooking a vast courtyard. 14   INCLUDE COURTYARD                                            14 Grim, funereal silence as a hundred Musketeers remove their blue and gold tunics, drop them into a pile that already contains their swords and muskets. The Musketeers remain stoic throughout, unwilling to reveal the depth of their despair. The latter is supervised by the Cardinal's Guards, who view their hated enemies' plight with satisfaction. This is a sad day for the Musketeers, the end of an era. MONSIEUR DE TREVILLE forces a salute toward the captain of the Cardinal's Guards, hands over his own musket. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 14   CONTINUED:                                                    14 Treville is the respected leader of the Musketeers.       This is the saddest moment of all. Rochefort watches from above, a cruel smile twists his lips. He steps to the railing, addresses the men below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers... A hundred faces turn   upward to regard him. And on each the same expression   -- absolute loathing for the man in black. Rochefort is    not intimidated by this sea of con- tempt. He revels in    it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By joint edict of His Majesty King Louis XIII and His Eminence Cardinal Richelieu, the Musketeers are officially disbanded. In preparation for the coming war with England, your ranks and commissions are hereby transferred to the Infantry. You will be contacted and told where to report. Until that time, you are instructed to return to your homes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who will protect the King?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cardinal's Guards are more than capable of assuming that... responsibility. Muttered curses and dissent throughout.       Rochefort raises his voice to be heard:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are hereby ordered to disperse. Should even one of you resist... the entire corps will be arrested and imprisoned. (with pleasure and disdain) 'All for one, and one for all.' As Rochefort intended, the Musketeers explode. But before they can attack the Guards, de Treville's com- manding voice calls out above the clamor. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 14   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers! And with that, the Musketeers freeze. Their eyes go to de Treville. There is a moment of silence as de Treville chooses his words carefully. Even in defeat, de Treville is stoic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to your homes. Wait. Our day will come again. De Treville shoots a defiant look at Rochefort who smiles in a patronizing manner. Then, de Treville leads his Musketeers out of the courtyard. 15   ROCHEFORT                                                  15 He returns to the adjoining room where Jussac stands by. Rochefort has enjoyed himself immensely. He goes to a mirror and preens, adjusting his eye patch to a more rak- ish angle. That's when he catches a glimpse of something behind him. Something red. Rochefort turns. a tall, powerfully built MAN stands in the shadows of the room, a spectre in red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Eminence. Rochefort and Jussac instantly fall to their knees. ARMAND DU PLEISS THE CARDINAL RICHELIEU steps out of the darkness and into the light, his long crimson robes swirling about him like clouds of blood. His face is long, shrewd and intelligent. His eyes are penetrat- ing. He smiles his crocodile smile. Richelieu observes a duty roster on one of the walls. It contains the names of all the Musketeers, past and present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have they all been accounted for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All but... three. On Richelieu's face, a flicker of irritation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 15   CONTINUED:                                                      15 JUSSAC (speaking up) I sent a patrol to find them but it hasn't returned yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want those Musketeers, not excuses. Bring them in at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 16   EXT. BOULEVARD OF CRIME - DAY                                   16 Jussac leads   a regiment of the Cardinal's Gruards down Paris' most   colorful and notorious street. They react to SHOUTING   and VIOLENT NOISES coming from a tavern ahead. The    one called... The Dead Rat. The tavern door flies open, and two of the Cardinal's Guards are flung into the street, bruised and bloody. Just then: A window on the second floor bursts open, and a big Musketeer dangles a struggling Guard by his feet, threatening to drop him into the street. The Musketeer, a man of enormous appetites -- wine, women, song -- is called PORTHOS. Jussac shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Release that man!! Happy to comply, Porthos lets go of the Guard who plunges to the street with a dull thud. Then, with a wink and a piratical grin, Porthos ducks inside. Jussac darkens, signals his men, and they rush toward the tavern. 17   INT. TAVERN                                                     17 Jussac and his company burst in and discover the room in a shambles, the aftermath of a violent fight. But for now, all is calm. A group of the Cardinal's Guards is seated around a big table littered with flagons and bottles. On the floor around them are their swords and rifles. It appears the Gruards are celebrating a victory. But wait. There's something wrong with this picture. On closer inspection, we see that the Guards have been stripped to their under- clothes and tied to their chairs with ropes. They are all bruised and bloody. Some are unconscious. Presiding over the "celebration" are two Musketeers. They sit at the head of the table, relaxing with their boots up. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 17   CONTINUED:                                                   17 One of them casually cleans his sword with a lace hand- kerchief. He is ARAMIS, the most handsome and dashing of the Musketeers -- a poet and idealist -- a gentleman of great personal charm and style. His companion is   ATHOS, the Musketeers' deadliest and most charismatic   member -- also its most mysterious and tortured. Athos    is the unofficial leader of the Three Musketeers, their   planner and strategist. At the moment, he's sewing up a   nasty gash on his right arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this? Athos greets him with a dark smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A private party. Go away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Athos -- is that any way to greet our guests? Aramis leaps to his feet and bows graciously.    He is the epitome of politeness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be shy, gentlemen. Come in. Your friends have been expecting you. Jussac is not amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your presence is requested at Musketeer Headquarters by Captain Rochefort. Athos and Aramis exchange looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cyclops is a Captain? He must've made a pact with the Devil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or the Cardinal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the difference? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 17   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Devil is more ethical than the Cardinal. Jussac takes a step forward, fingering his saber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're instructed to come with me and surrender your tunics. With a sweeping gesture, Athos indicates the bloody Guards around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These gentlemen made a similar request.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you refusing to come peaceably?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably. But I'll leave it up to my companions. Aramis?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't refuse Rochefort's invitation. It would be impolite. Athos tips back in his chair and gazes upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what do you say, Porthos? To the Guards' surprise, Porthos is balancing on the balcony rail above, just about even with a large wagon wheel chandelier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be right down! With the grace of an aerialist, Porthos jumps from the balcony and lands atop the chandelier. His weight causes the chains suspending it to break. With a whoop of pleasure, Porthos rides the chandelier down as it lands squarely atop Jussac's Guards, squashing them. When the dust clears, only Jussac has been spared. He looks on in disbelief as Porthos extricates himself from the wreckage and calmly brushes his clothes off. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 17   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready when you are. Athos and Aramis sheathe their swords, put on their hats, wrap their capes around them and cross the room to join Porthos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Congratulations, Porthos.   You brought down the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My aim was off. I was trying to hit Jussac. Athos fixes Jussac with a dark, threatening look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now.   About those tunics... Jussac turns to watch Athos, Porthos, and Aramis step to the street. He mutters as if to curse:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 18   EXT. HIGH ROAD TO PARIS - DAY                                  18 D'Artagnan, on horseback, pauses on a bluff overlook- ing the magnificent city on the Seine. What he beholds is Paris as it looked in the early part of the Seven- teenth Century, its steeples and towers rising to meet the sky. For a country boy like d'Artagnan, Paris is a magical place where the wildest of dreams can come true. D'Artagnan's reverie is broken by the sound of THUNDERING HOOFBEATS coming from behind. He turns in response and what he sees is this: Two women on horseback are riding for all they're worth pursued by two men on horseback. 19   D'ARTAGNAN                                                     19 His heroic blood stirs. Women in danger! As the women GALLOP past, d'Artagnan leaps from his horse. Quickly formulating a plan, he clambers up the trunk of a nearby tree and climbs out on a branch that overhangs the road. 14. 20   ANGLE                                                       20 As the two riders pass underneath, d'Artagnan leaps into space and tackles one of them, knocking him out of the saddle. The rider hits the ground and is knocked sense- less. One down. D'Artagnan scrambles to his feet as the second rider re- verses direction and GALLOPS back, charging d'Artagnan. The rider draws his saber. D'Artagnan dodges the horse and the sword. He catches the second rider's arm and yanks him right out of the saddle. The man lands with a painful thud at d'Artagnan's feet. Before he can recover, d'Artagnan is upon him with flying fists. One swift punch -- and the second rider is senseless. Two down. D'Artagnan stands over his two victims, out of breath, but greatly pleased with his performance. He looks up as the two women ride back to see what's happened. The first woman is of noble breeding, a beautiful dark- haired girl in her late teens. Her name is ANNE. Her companion is roughly the same age, titan-haired and equally beautiful. Her name is CONSTANCE. Anne regards the two men on the ground, then d'Artagnan. She shakes her head, laughs with delight and rides off. Constance remains. She smiles down at d'Artagnan from atop her horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have any idea what you've done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've saved you and your friend from these bandits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These 'bandits' are the Queen's own bodyguards. D'Artagnan is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Queen? Constance points a finger in Anne's direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I were you, I'd make myself scarce. These men are going to be very angry when they wake up. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 20   CONTINUED:                                                     20 D'Artagnan looks at the two bodyguards who are beginning to recover. Then he looks up at Constance, feeling like a prize idiot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know. I thought... Constance smiles at him, her eyes twinkling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have a name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a very foolish boy, d'Artagnan... but a very handsome one. Good-bye. Constance spurs her horse and rides off to catch up with Anne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait!   You didn't tell me your name! But Constance is gone. D'Artagnan stands in the middle of the road, feeling foolish and oddly thrilled at the same time. The two bodyguards groan and grumble. A bright reflection catches d'Artagnan's eye. He looks down and sees a gleaming bracelet. He picks it up and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man who attacked you... (pointing in the opposite direction) ... went that way. With a guilty smile, d'Artagnan spurs his horse and rides like Hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 21   EXT. COUNTRY ROAD                                              21 D'Artagnan rides to the top of the ridge, stops suddenly, sees something that takes his breath away. 16. 22   D'ARTAGNAN'S POV                                             22 Paris laid out for him like a jewel, cloaked in mystery, promising adventure and romance. D'Artagnan watches the women as they ride into the fabled city in the distance. He follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take those tunics, Musketeers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did he say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said he'll take those tunics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tunics?   Coming right up. Porthos reaches inside his cloak and takes out a crumpled red tunic he took from one of the Cardinal's guards. He drops it on the ground, digs into a pocket and takes out another. He finds another in his boot and another up his sleeve. There's one in his hat. Like a magician, he keeps pulling red tunics out of the most bizarre places. Athos and Aramis have a few guard tunics themselves. They pull them out and drop them into the growing pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was trying to remember the last time I saw you here. I know. It was the day you were kicked out of the Musketeers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Conduct Unbecoming a Musketeer. Wasn't that the charge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ought to know. Three witnesses stood against me. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 23   CONTINUED:                                                      23 ATHOS It was the least we could do. The bitter memory hangs in the air for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are hereby ordered to surrender your commissions and make yourselves available for reassignment in the King's Army.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if we refuse?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will become outlaws.   Hunted men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't matter where I go or what I do. Sooner or later somebody's calling me 'outlaw.' Athos cuts him off with a look. He's familiar with Porthos' propensity for tall tales. But not here, not now. Athos turns back to the balcony. Rochefort lobs a taunt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you refusing to serve your King?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are refusing to serve the Cardinal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Same thing, these days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: France has one King too many.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell him you said that. Athos, who has remained silent, speaks with quiet power:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do that, Rochefort. Tell his Emminence the Cardinal that we will continue to perform our sworn duty to protect the King. From enemies across the sea. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 23   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From traitors who sit at his right hand. And tell him that he can take away our tunics, our muskets, even our swords. But he cannot stop us from being what we are. Musketeers. The gauntlet has been thrown.       Rochefort picks it up with glee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll make sure His Emminence the Cardinal gets the message. But I can't promise he'll be pleased. Rochefort steps back, disappears into the shadows.       A beat. The Musketeers regard each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if we're going to be outlaws, I suppose we'll have to get our affairs in order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going to visit them alphabetically or in order of preference?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alphabetically seems... fair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When it comes to you and women, fairness rarely applies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll meet at the Columbier-Rouge at sundown. (off their looks) To celebrate. And to plan our new lives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outlaws.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Citizens of France.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three Musketeers. And that is all that remains. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 23   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look out!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaarrgghh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are they? Where are the Musketeers? I'm in the right place, aren't I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not as far as I'm concerned. Athos is wearing his cape in such a way that it hides his Musketeer tunic. D'Artagnan has no idea who he's dealing with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But this is Musketeer Headquarters... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 25   CONTINUED:                                                     25 ATHOS No. This was Musketeer Headquarters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean it's been moved?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean the Musketeers have been disbanded. Feel free to poke around for souvenirs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean 'disbanded'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some nonsense about being needed in the army. Now if you'll excuse me... D'Artagnan blocks Athos' path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I just got here. How can I become a Musketeer if they've been disbanded?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd say you've got a problem. D'Artagnan grabs Athos by his injured arm. Athos, stif- ling pain, fixes d'Artagnan with a deadly look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could use a lesson in manners. D'Artagnan touches his sword, eyes flashing at the pos- sibility of a duel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm in a hurry now -- but I'll meet you at the Carmes-Deshaux monastery at noon. Athos exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be there ten minutes early. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 25   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An hour in Paris, and I already have my first duel! Just then, d'Artangnan spies two familiar figures on horseback, distinctive cloaks hiding their faces. Anne and Constance, though he does not yet know their names. D'Artagnan hurries after.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Catherine, don't you see? As an outlaw I'll be constantly on the run from the Cardinal's guards, a refugee. Think of all the places you can hide me. I'm thinking of them now. 27   ANOTHER ANGLE                                          27 reveals Porthos leaning against an open window, speaking amiably to a pretty woman on the other side. She dabs a tear from her eye, manages a nod. 28   ANGLE ON D'ARTAGNAN                                    28 Meanwhile, d'Artagnan races around another corner, down a narrow lane, and speeds after the ladies on horseback. He dashes through a muddy puddle -- spraying foul water all over Porthos where he stands. D'Artagnan doesn't notice, a huge cart loaded with wine barrels has rolled INTO VIEW, blocking the lane. Fellow travelers shout complaints, the cart driver shakes his head, makes an obscene gesture. It's a Seventeenth Century traffic jam. D'Artagnan sees Anne and Constance dismount in the dis- tance, tie their horses, and step into an alley. A man waits in the shadows to escort them. D'Artagnan leaps off his horse, he means to continue his pursuit on foot. But he takes two quick steps, and... runs directly into Porthos' outstretched hand. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 28   CONTINUED:                                                         28 D'Artagnan looks up -- literally, given Porthos' impres- sive stature -- and sees the Musketeer's muddied tunic, and worse, a unique and expensive sash, now thoroughly soiled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know where this sash comes from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a gift from the Queen of America. Porthos' righteous indignation is more impressive than his knowledge of current affairs. D'Artagnan corrects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no Queen of America.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame Augustine, would you excuse me for a moment, I'm going to kill him. (back to d'Artagnan; ever the gentleman) Now, where were we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I rode through a puddle, muddied your sash, the Queen of America except there isn't one, I'm in a hurry, and you were about to challenge me to a duel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That seems to be the local custom. Porthos lets out a weary sigh.         He shakes his head. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 28   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everywhere I go, it's always the same. There's always some kid who thinks he's hot with a sword... some itchy punk who wants to go up against the great Porthos...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The great who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The great Porthos. (when d'Artagnan isn't impressed) Me, you idiot. D'Artagnan gives him a blank look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you know who I am?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The world's greatest talker? Porthos couldn't be more insulted.       He sputters with rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, you little puke! You want to die? So be it! One o'clock behind the Luxembourg! And bring a coffin!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bring your own! 29   EXT. STREETS OF PARIS - ALLEY - DAY                               29 D'Artagnan thinks he sees     Anne and Constance, races down the alley, turns a corner,     down a short street, makes a hasty decision, runs down     yet another alley... and tum- bles into a shadowy lane.      He stops, looks left and right. And does see them. The ladies enter a chapel's back door, close the door behind them. D'Artagnan flies after, skids across cob- blestones, rips the door open... and finds himself face to face with the man who has escorted Anne and Constance this far.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me pass. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 29   CONTINUED:                                                      29 CARDINAL'S GUARD I'm afraid that's not possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must speak to those young women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young women do not wish to be spoken to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have something that belongs to the Queen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bracelet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll deliver it for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you've been enough help already. Would you be so kind as to point out the Carmes-Deshaux Monastery? The Guard points to a large building in the distance with a large cross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 30   INT. ROOM                                                       30 PAN ACROSS the Virgin Mary and many lit candles to a BEAUTIFUL DAMSEL sharing a love seat with the third Musketeer, the dashing Aramis. Aramis has a book open and is reading from it. The Damsel suddenly grabs Aramis and kisses him on the mouth. Aramis politely extricates himself. He's not the least bit embarrassed, only slightly amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madam, I'm flattered but I thought you wanted me to tutor you in theology. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 30   CONTINUED:                                                          30 DAMSEL Excuse me, Monsieur Aramis. But when you started talking about Original Sin, I lost control and became impassioned. It won't happen again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing unholy about expressing one's emotions. On the contrary. Religion should be experienced in a passionate, all- embracing way. We should feel free to express our spirituality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, darling! The Damsel attacks him again.         Suddenly, a pounding on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My husband!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your husband!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aramis -- run! But Aramis' heart is too noble.         He gets down on his knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First we must pray to God for forgiveness. That's when the door bursts open and the lady's husband, an irate MARQUIS enters with a pistol. His eyes blaze with madness. He aims the pistol at Aramis' head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On second thought, God's often busy. Aramis leaps to his feet and sprints for the open window. As the Marquis aims and FIRES, Aramis puts one foot on the ledge and leaps into space. The shot misses him by inches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 31   STREET BELOW                                                 31 As d'Artagnan runs past. Aramis lands on top of him and they go crashing to the cobblestones. As they untangle themselves and get up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. You broke my fall perfectly. But I do apologize for the inconvenience...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get off me! D'Artagnan pushes Aramis aside. Aramis grabs d'Artagnan by the scruff of his neck and pulls him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If there's one thing I can't abide, it's rudeness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fell on me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I apologized for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose you'd like to teach me a lesson in manners, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd be honored. D'Artagnan brightens.   Another duel!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's two o'clock behind the Luxembourg? Aramis bows politely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If that's where you wish to die, I won't disappoint you. Until then... Aramis takes off.   d'Artagnan swells with pride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three duels in one day. I love this town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 32   EXT. LOUVRE - DAY                                            32 The Royal Palace of Louis XIII.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you seen the King?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Your Majesty. 33   INT. THRONE ROOM - DAY                                       33 Anne, or rather, Queen Anne, steps into the throne room, a massive cathedral-like chamber. Twin thrones occupy a raised dais. An entire wall is covered with a spectac- ular map of the world. The map contains every known country and continent, including the New World. The SENESCHAL exits, closing the doors with a resounding boom. Anne pauses, all alone in the big, drafty chamber. And for the first time, she looks and acts her age. Barely a woman, chilled by the ghosts of all the French kings and queens who came before her. And a long way from home. Anne steps to the great map of the world. She reaches out to touch her own country, Austria, feels a pang of separation. We hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Majesty... Anne reacts with a start. A tall, powerfully built man stands in the shadows, a spectre in red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cardinal Richelieu, you surprised me. Cardinal Richelieu steps out of the darkness.     He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How was your ride? Richelieu's question takes her by surprise. He bows before Anne. Considering a reply, she extends her hand. The Cardinal kisses it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My ride...?    Well, I... I'm not sure...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 33   CONTINUED:                                                     33 RICHELIEU (CONT'D) But your welfare is more than a matter of personal interest. It is a matter of State. But rest assured, your secret is safe with me. His manner is both charming and paternal. Anne, smart enough to exercise caution in all her palace dealings, is nonetheless touched by his concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Richelieu turns to the great map, speaks gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're homesick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonely. Is that the same thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes. Richelieu brings his eyes back to Anne, continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Austria's loss is France's gain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure my new husband shares your opinion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nonsense.    He's young, not blind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mostly, he is absent. I've barely seen His Majesty since our wedding, and that was three months ago. Whenever he's around me, he has nothing to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arranged marriages can be difficult. Your father and I thought yours would bring Austria and France closer together. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 33   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countries align more swiftly than people, I'm afraid. Louis and I remain... far apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I advise you? He says it with seeming humility, not condescension.        Anne nods assent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Louis was only nine years old when his father was assassinated. He lost his childhood forever that day. I have watched him grow toward manhood, seen the toll his life demands. A boy who is not allowed to be a boy sometimes has difficulty becoming a man. He is shy, yet boastful. Giving, yet stubborn. But most of all, he is not yet sure exactly who he is. The boy who lost his father. Or the King of France.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But how can I...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flatter him. Make the boy feel like a King. So that the King may be your husband. Anne considers his eloquent advice, formulates a reply... when the huge doors to the throne room open with a dull boom, the Seneschal chants:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His Majesty, the King. The Seneschal steps aside as LOUIS XIII enters. He is surprisingly young, no older than d'Artagnan. His face is handsome and intelligent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cardinal Richelieu, I've been looking for you. As Louis strides toward them, Richelieu and Anne bow. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 33   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Anne. Hello. I didn't know you were here. Louis hides his nervousness, not to mention his love, behind a formal veneer. Anne, emboldened by Richelieu's confidences, replies:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like me to go? Louis suddenly remembers the reason he's here.       Determin- ation breeds a more capable attitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  Please, stay. (to Richelieu, aware that she is watching him) Your Eminence, I demand an answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps if I knew the question...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've just been told that you went ahead and disbanded my Musketeers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You approved the decision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But not the timing of the matter. I intended to address them myself, explain the situation...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Majesty, France is on the brink of war. We dare not hesitate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But these men are my personal guards...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are the bravest fighters in France. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 33   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll need them in the field if we're to win this war with England. Buckingham plans to invade La Rochelle within the month. I thought it best to act quickly -- LOUIS I will be the judge of what is best. For me, and for France. He says it with newfound resolve. Richelieu receives the rebuke with quiet grace. Anne watches the latter closely, suppresses a smile. The boy is nearer to King than Richelieu imagined.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.   Forgive me. A tense beat.    Anne, feeling out of place, steps toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne?   Are you all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You two should continue this discussion in private.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your thoughts on the matter interest me. They might... help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seems to me that... you're doing very well on your own. She means it.    Anne smiles, exits.      A beat.   Louis sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extremely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Intelligent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 33   CONTINUED:    (5)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes she scares me half to death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I advise you? Repetition reveals calculation. Louis nods.       And the Cardinal surprises with quiet humor:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She scares me too. As do all women who join beauty to intelligence. What's a man to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The course of love is full of frightful turns. But, no matter how you feel, no matter how hopelessly afraid... never let her know that you are anything other than the bravest and most confident man in France. Make that your starting point, and everything else will fall... into place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bravest man in France...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good advice for a shopkeeper. Let alone a King. A beat. Richelieu acting as the lost father.        And Louis appreciating it, speaking as a son:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Eminence, I'm sorry that I was sharp with you. It's just that the Musketeers... well, they're not just my guards. They're my friends too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.   But don't worry. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 33   CONTINUED:    (6)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From now on, I'll take complete responsibility for your welfare. Indeed he will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 34   INT./EXT. THRONE ROOM/HALLWAY - DAY                             34 Richelieu bursts out of the Throne Room and is joined by Rochefort. Walking quickly down a long hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a foolish boy. And barely that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That foolish boy is about to become a man. (off Rochefort's look) Which is all the more reason for us to act... quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the Queen...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She will receive me in ways she never thought possible. Privately. HOLD ON the Cardinal and Rochefort, watching the King and Queen below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 35   EXT. STREETS OF PARIS - DAY                                     35 D'Artagnan walks proudly toward the Carmes-Deschaux monastery, bold and brave, his future at hand. Suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of the way, idiot!! A speeding carriage bears down on him. D'Artagnan leaps from its path, stumbles. He looks up in time to see the passenger inside, and for a moment, time seems to stop. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 35   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 36 A beautiful house situated near the Seine. Milady's carriage stops before it. She steps to the street, Parker follows. After a brief spoken exchange, the body- guard departs on some errand. HENRI, the driver, a brutal- looking fellow, incongruous in his elegant coachman's uniform, snaps the reins, and guides the carriage away. Milady steps inside. 37   ANOTHER ANGLE - POV                                         37 REVEALS this to have been the POV of two men standing in the shadows across the street. COUNT DE WINTER, forty- five, a kind face etched with sadness, and ARMAND DE WINTER, twenty-five, his son. They are well-dressed. But their manner and appearance suggests that they have traveled a long distance to find her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Father...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait. He will not consider otherwise. Armand sighs, stands in the shadows, and watches his father cross toward Milady's house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 38   INT. MILADY'S HOUSE - DAY                                   38 Milady stands before a mirror, reaches for one of the many ivory combs that adorn her hair. As she places the comb we notice a small flower-like tattoo on her arm. She pauses to admire her beauty, then to see the image of Count de Winter, now standing behind her, his eyes dark and cold. Milady does not move from the reflecting glass, she smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Count de Winter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We found you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Now that you have, what will you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bring you back. To pay for what you did to my son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if I resist...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will kill you with my bare hands. The Count steps closer, close enough to touch. Milady, eyes bright with excitement, the smile still playing about her lips, replies:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well if that's the case, I'd better start packing. But first, my hair... Milady, who has been removing combs throughout, reaches for the next, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 40   INT. MILADY'S HOUSE - DAY                                    40 Armand climbs a flight of stairs.    Still no sign of his father, or Milady. He calls out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father? Worry makes him hurry. Armand takes hasty steps into Milady's bedroom. The first thing he sees is his own face in the mirror. The second is his father's inert body below it. Armand gasps, races to his side. A thin trail of bright blood is seen briefly at the older man's ear. Armand gathers his father up into his arms, and begins to weep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten minutes early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have another appointment at one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll miss it, I'm afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll try my best to be on time. Athos appreciates the young man's retort, takes a closer look. Then he rises to his feet, the pain in his arm makes him wince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I asked two of my friends to act as seconds, but they are not as punctual. D'Artagnan notices Athos' pained expression, the blood on his sleeve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're wounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry. I fight just as well with my left hand. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 41   CONTINUED:                                                     41 D'ARTAGNAN If you'd rather kill me another time...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, but I see my seconds coming now. Porthos and Aramis arrive on horseback. They dismount, view d'Artagnan with amazement. D'Artagnan reacts with similar surprise, smiles sheepishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you doing? You can't fight this man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I'm fighting him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, monsieur. But not until one o'clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute. I've got a duel with him, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.   But not until two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been in Paris?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I arrived this morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been... busy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've also fallen in love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better to die for love than to live for it. Gentlemen? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 41   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There they are!! Athos and d'Artagnan separate as Jussac and his four swordsmen stride towards them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jussac.   Again. Athos steps forward to meet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you the next time we met I'd want an answer. But I didn't expect you so soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three of you are under arrest. The boy's of no interest to me and is free to go. Do you intend to resist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, don't be stupid. Of course we intend to resist. Just give us a second. Porthos huddles with Athos and Aramis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Interesting odds. Five of them and three of us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It hardly seems fair. Let's give them the chance to surrender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, but there are four of us. They turn and regard d'Artagnan. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 41   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not your fight.    You're not a Musketeer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I may not wear the uniform, but I believe I have the heart of a Musketeer. The three Musketters exchange smiles. D'Artagnan's youthful bravado manages a small dent in their cynicism.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bold and brave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A poet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you got a name, boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan? The name has meaning for all of them. The Musketeers look at each other, deadpan, shake their heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It couldn't be. Athos knows that it is. He steps forward, extends a hand. The others follow, shake as well. Athos intro- duces each in turn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Athos... Porthos... Aramis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pleased to meet you... How do you do?... Good to see you again... Meanwhile, Jussac and his Guards look on with increasing impatience. He clears his throat, draws his saber. The Musketeers turn toward the Guards, d'Artagnan standing among them. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 41   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. Now that we're all acquainted...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cardinal's Guards. D'Artagnan and the Musketeers draw their swords... and charge. 42   FIGHT                                                      42 Suddenly: nine men are locked in mortal combat. Athos takes a Guard named Cahusac, Porthos battles BISCARAT, and Aramis battles with two adversaries at once. D'Artagnan looks for an opponent... and finds himself face to face with Jussac. The fighting style of the Musketeers is an exuberant mix- ture of styles and techniques. Athos is a brutal swords- man, his strokes overpowering and savage. His repertoire also includes swift kicks, solid punches, the occasional elbow when necessary. Aramis is a seamless and graceful technician, he handles his two opponents with balletic ease, an artist working with steel and flesh, rather than paint and canvas. And last, and perhaps the most entertaining of all, Porthos. He is a walking arsenal, carrying a variety of bizarre weapons on his body -- a crossbow, daggers, bolo, nunchucks -- all of which he uses with the polished skill of a master. Add this funhouse of armaments to his already impressive size and strength, and you have a one- man wrecking crew of epic proportions. D'Artagnan's youthful energy is by now familiar. He bounds about like a newborn tiger, encircles his adver- sary, changing stance and shifting his ground with alac- rity. Jussac is having a hard time defending himself against his opponent who seems to be attacking from all directions at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stand still! How do you expect me to kill you if you keep jumping around!! 43   MONASTERY                                                  43 A monk watches from the bell tower, incensed by the battle raging on the field below. He grabs the BELL rope, gives it a mighty pull... and sounds a clamorous ALARM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 44   BACK TO SCENE                                               44 Porthos reacts to the interruption with irritation. He produces a pair of nunchucks. Biscarat looks at the odd weapon with professional curiosity, slight confusion... and Porthos whacks him on the side of the head, knocks him to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn monks. Always spoiling everybody's fun. Aramis replies while shifting from one foe to the next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are nearer to God...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're about to get a little nearer to the hilt of my sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pagan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papist. Porthos slides over to handle one of Aramis' opponents. He'd rather bicker from close range. But Biscarat struggles to his feet, grabs his saber. Porthos sees him, sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine, thank you. And Porthos returns to his original foe. Meanwhile, Athos' heavy strokes take their toll. Cahusac staggers, wounded in arm, shoulder, grazed at the head -- and falls to the ground with a thud. Aramis calls out to him, indicates d'Artagnan:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a look at our young friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean he's still alive? Not only is d'Artagnan alive, but he's making a fool out of Jussac.  Frustrated, enraged, Jussac makes a full lunge at him, but d'Artagnan ducks, then slips under Jussac's sword like a snake and runs him through. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 44   CONTINUED:                                                     44 Jussac falls to the ground, lies still.    He is dead. Athos and Aramis react, impressed. Then turn their full attention on weakening foes. They disarm and disable them with swift strokes. Meanwhile, Porthos chases Biscarat into a grove of trees. The Guard has discovered the better part of valor, now runs for his life. Porthos -- who is at play as much as he is war -- takes a Spanish bolo from his cloak, and whips the balls over his head. Biscarat hears the odd WHIZZING sound, turns to face him. The color drains from his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now what...? Porthos lets the bolo fly -- it catches Biscarat about the neck, the balls slam into his head. The Guard drops to the ground without a sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, I love my work. 45   AFTERMATH                                                      45 A sudden silence, save for the occasional dull groan. D'Artagnan scans the battlefield, sees Aramis bending over Jussac's body, speaking in solemn tones under his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last rites. Aramis takes death very seriously. Porthos returns in high spirits, stashes the bolo in a pouch under his cloak. D'Artagnan sees the other weapons there, including a boomerang. Maybe next time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know where this bolo comes from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Queen of America?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spain. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 45   CONTINUED:                                                        45 Porthos deadpans, then grins acceptance.      All for one, and one for all. D'Artagnan beams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't encourage him. By killing Jussac, the boy's made himself an outlaw too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not if he leaves Paris. Which is exactly what he's going to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't leave. I just got here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go home, find a wench, live long and prosper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why can't I stay with you? Aramis and Porthos look to Athos.      As always, he will decide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I do not want you to. It's hard to say whether he's acting out of concern for the boy... or he simply doesn't give a damn. Whatever the case, d'Artagnan is crestfallen. The Musketeers mount their horses, Porthos and Aramis adopt a friendlier tone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know Athos may seem cold and unfriendly, but don't let that fool you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He really is cold and unfriendly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he's also right. This is our fight, not yours. Go on, get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever happened to the motto of the Musketeers? 'All for one, and one for all.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up, boy.    The Musketeers are just a dream. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 45   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There they go! After them! But before Rochefort and the Guards can give chase, d'Artagnan rides into the middle of the field to challenge them, as if to further prove himself worthy of the blue and gold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long live the Musketeers. And d'Artagnan draws his saber. AT DISTANCE The three Muskeeters rein their horses, look back to d'Artagnan's bold charge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you believe this kid. D'Artagnan gallops toward the Guards to engage them.    He races through PISTOL SHOTS like a demon possessed. Rochefort rides to the lead, draws his sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fall back! I'll take him myself! And like two jousting knights, d'Artagnan and   Rochefort meet in the middle of the field. Their BLADES    connect with a resounding CLASH, d'Artagnan is knocked   clear of his saddle. He hits the ground with a painful    thud. Rochefort's Guards leap towards him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 46   ANGLE TO INCLUDE MUSKEERS                                    46 Porthos and Aramis are greatly moved by d'Artagnan's courage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rochefort's got the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't just leave him. Athos spurs his horse, rides away. Aramis and Porthos exchange sad looks and hopeful comments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has a plan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Definitely.   A plan. And with that, they gallop after. 47   BACK TO SCENE                                                47 Meanwhile, d'Artagnan is soon outnumbered, and quickly subdued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This boy fights like a wildcat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. The Guard clobbers d'Artagnan with the scabbard of his sword. The last thing d'Artagnan sees is the three Musketeers riding into the distance. Then the WORLD TILTS, GOES SUDDENLY BLACK. FADE IN: 48   EXT. BASTILLE - NIGHT                                        48 The walls and towers of France's most infamous prison rise to meet a starless sky. The portcullis is raised by men-at-arms, admitting a spectacular crimson carriage pulled by a team of snow-white stallions. The emblem of the Cardinal of France is emblazoned on the carriage door, and THROUGH its WINDOW we see the profile of Richelieu. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 48   CONTINUED:                                                     48 Lovingly, he fingers the upholstery of his extravagant carriage. CUT TO: 49   INT. DUNGEON - NIGHT                                           49 A chamber in hell. Spiders the size of rats, rats the size of small dogs. A foul stench in the air. D'Artagnan is sprawled in a corner, unconscious, on a filthy matted floor. The sharp tip of a sword pokes him in the chest. D'Artagnan wakes with a start, springs back into action. As if he was still battling Jussac at the Carmes-Deschaux. He slaps the sword away, leaps to his feet, and reaches for his own. But it is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My sword -- ROCHEFORT It's magnificent. Where did you get it? Rochefort steps INTO VIEW, the familiar eyepatch, admiring d'Artagnan's sword in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It belonged to my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father... Rochefort studies d'Artagnan for a long moment, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well now it belongs to me. I collect swords. I take them from the men I kill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not dead yet. D'Artagnan starts forward. But Rochefort raises the sword, points it at his throat. D'Artagnan freezes, feels the sharp tip of the blade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soon enough. Rochefort shoves d'Artagnan back to the floor with a heavy boot. A beat. D'Artagnan peers at his dismal surroundings. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 49   CONTINUED:                                                     49 D'ARTAGNAN Where am I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll give you a hint. It's not the Louvre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Bastille! I'm in the Bastille!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're the first person who was ever happy to be here. Unfortunately, your visit will be a short one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You killed one of the Cardinal's Guards. An offense punishable by death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He interrupted a duel I was fighting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Also punishable by death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was a long day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Musketeers. D'Artagnan says nothing.     He will not betray them. Rochefort leans close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me where they are, and I will be lenient.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 49   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will give you your father's sword. A long beat. D'Artagnan eyes the gleaming saber, forged in the Crusades. He nods, gestures for Rochefort to come closer. As if to impart a secret. Rochefort tilts downward, d'Artagnan rises up... and whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me my father's sword, and I'll cut out your heart. Bold words, bad timing. Rochefort snarls, slams the hilt of the sword into d'Artagnan's head. The youth slumps from the wooden stool to the floor, unconscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fool.   Like your father. Rochefort storms from the cell. He nods at a grizzled jailer on his way out, indicates the chains and manacles on the cell wall. The jailer scurries over to d'Artagnan, inert in a shallow puddle of foul water. He lifts, drags him toward the chains -- but d'Artagnan's eyes pop open, the jailer reacts with surprise, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 50   INT. BASTILLE - CORRIDOR - NIGHT                              50 The jailer exits from d'Artagnan's cell, closes the heavy door behind him. A CLOSER look reveals d'Artagnan in the jailer's soiled tunic, eyes bright with adventure. He looks left and right -- dank corridors, darkness, the OCCASIONAL GROAN. And steps lightly into the shadows. 51   ON D'ARTAGNAN                                                 51 He seeks exit, finds only a labyrinth. Two jailers con- verse, step towards him. D'Artagnan leaps into a cell doorway, allows them to pass. Suddenly: scabrous hands reach from inside the cell, grab d'Artagnan by the throat. He shudders, leaps free. And continues. D'Artagnan steps     deeper in the labyrinth. Frustrated, no way out. Just      then: more FOOTSTEPS heading toward him. D'Artagnan      seeks refuge, watches as a cloaked figure steps INTO     VIEW, accompanied by a retinue of sullen jailers. D'Artagnan thinks fast... and joins them. CUT TO: 49. 52   INT. BASTILLE - NIGHT                                       52 D'Artagnan keeps step with the cloaked figure, the ret- inue. He keeps his head down, glances at the corridor ahead, looking for a way out. But the cloaked figure is escorted up a long stairway, into another hall, and toward a pristine wooden door. D'Artagnan watches as the door opens, revealing... Cardinal Richelieu, a fear- some apparition in red, the most powerful man in France. D'Artagnan's jaw drops. The cloaked figure steps inside. The jailers disperse. D'Artagnan takes steps as if to join them... then turns back, eyes the door, the Cardinal and the cloaked figure now behind it. 53   ANGLE TO INCLUDE INTERIOR                                   53 The cloaked figure bows to the Cardinal. Richelieu smiles, concupiscent. Rochefort stands in a corner, ignored for the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have an errand that requires your singular talents. The figure rises. The hood falls back... revealing the unforgettable features of Milady de Winter. She answers the Cardinal's smile with a seductive expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was beginning to think you'd forgotten me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget you?   Impossible. Richelieu and Milady share a look of intimacy, two vipers from the same pit. 54   OUTSIDE DOOR                                                54 D'Artagnan slips closer, reaches for the handle, finds it unlocked. He opens the door a fraction, holds an ear close... 55   BACK TO SCENE                                               55 Richelieu produces a sealed document from his sleeve, and hands it to Milady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carry this to the Duke of Buckingham. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 55   CONTINUED:                                                      55 MILADY (impressed) You did it. An alliance with Buckingham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King left me no choice. Now that he's come of age, the boy believes he should rule France. Instead of me. Rochefort knows what this portends.    He steps from the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to go through with ... everything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Everything. (to Milady) You're to leave for Calais at once. A ship called the Persephone will carry you to England. It sails Tuesday, midnight. I want Buckingham's signature next to mine before the King's birthday. Friday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Consider it done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And doing so, shall earn you the gratitude of... a King. Richelieu's not talking about Louis.    He's talking about himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 56   INT. BASTILLE - CORRIDOR - NIGHT                                56 D'Artagnan leaps back from the door as it opens, head down, shuffles to join the retinue of jailers as they RETURN TO VIEW. Milady, unrecognizable behind her cloak, steps into the corridor, the retinue escorts her forward. D'Artagnan falls into place, eyes down, eager for escape. Just then: a hand slams down upon his shoulder. D'Artagnan looks up into the face of Captain Rochefort. 51. 57   EXT. BASTILLE - MILADY'S COACH                               57 Exiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On your knees. When d'Artagnan fails to respond, Rochefort gives him a mighty kick. D'Artagnan scrambles into the correct posture of supplication. Rochefort continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the boy who killed Jussac.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can explain that -- ROCHEFORT Silence! Rochefort punches d'Artagnan in the head, knocking him to the floor. The Cardinal frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rochefort. Violence solves nothing. Leave him to me. D'Artagnan reacts to the Cardinal's reasonable tone. Rochefort makes a sullen exit. The Cardinal smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.    Sit down. D'Artagnan reacts with perceptible awe, as if seeing his first movie star. He sits in a finely brocaded chair, looks at the Cardinal, an apparition in red. The Cardinal speaks, his manner casual, friendly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much did you hear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a word, Your Eminence. I stepped from my cell for a breath of air, and became lost in the corridors, it's dark as you know, but then I saw a light up ahead, the light over your door, I... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 58   CONTINUED:                                                     58 Richelieu smiles, dismisses d'Artagnan's tale with a wave of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may have many talents, my young friend. But guile is not one of them. Do you have a name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've heard that name before.   Are you a Gascon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Your Eminence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me. What brought you to Paris. And don't say 'a horse.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came to join the King's Musketeers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bad timing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I've heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan, I like you. I could use a capable young man like you in my Guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm honored, Your Eminence, but I don't think I would be very popular with the other men. Not after today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose not. Your heart is set on being a Musketeer. (off his look) When I was your age, I too had dreams of joining the Musketeers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You, Your Eminence? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 58   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Becoming a Musketeer is the fantasy of every young Frenchman. Or should I say it was... (with seeming kindness, reason) Like the Knights of the Round Table, the Musketeers have outlived their usefulness. They are a thing of the past. (beat) And so have your three friends.
