Tell me where they are, d'Artagnan, and I will spare your life. Richelieu's seeming kindness conceals a heart of ice. D'Artagnan sees it now, replies quietly. No longer in awe, but in opposition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. But I can't tell you what I do not know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In that case, give my regards to the headsman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about my trial?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've just had it. Richelieu turns for the door, means to dismiss him. D'Artagnan calls after.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait -- RICHELIEU Why? Do you object to losing your head?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.   I like it where it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then tell me what I want to know, and perhaps you will keep it there a few years longer. (beat) Where are the three Musketeers? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 58   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if you did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I admire your courage, young man. You might have made a fine Musketeer after all. Richelieu opens the door.       Rochefort waits on the other side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we'll never know, will we? Rochefort steps into the room, grabs d'Artagnan roughly by the arm, hurls him from the chair to the floor. This time Richelieu does not utter protest. Instead, he turns to the Captain, commands:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Find the three Musketeers and kill them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll be dead by dawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A comforting thought. Good night, d'Artagnan. Enjoy it. Morning comes quickly. With that, Cardinal Richelieu sweeps into the dark.       HOLD ON d'Artagnan for a beat. History's pawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 59   EXT. BASTILLE - MARKET SQUARE - DAY                            59 BELLS TOLL. A motley crowd gathers around the execution scaffold, held back by men-at-arms. A hooded executioner mounts the steps of the scaffold in the company of a PRIEST. The Priest wears a black cassock and a broad black sombrero. The executioner, a large man, raises his axe and touches the end of the blade, cutting his finger. Razor-sharp. The executioner holds up his bloody thumb. (CONTINUED) 55. 59   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milady left at midnight.   By private coach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A remarkable woman. The most beautiful I've ever known. And the deadliest. Which would explain my attraction. (peering down at the scene) How is our young daredevil holding up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's wishing he'd never heard of the Musketeers. Down below, the horse cart reaches the scaffold. A man- at-arms drops the tailgate, d'Artagnan steps down. He is taken into the custody of a CAPTAIN OF THE GUARDS, and several men-at-arms carrying muskets. 61   ANOTHER ANGLE                                             61 The Cardinal's familiar carriage is parked a safe distance from the square. The Guards who attend it have wandered off to watch the festivities. The coachman remains, seated on top, braiding his whip. Suddenly, a gloved hand grabs the coachman, yanks him from his seat. 62   SCAFFOLD                                                  62 D'Artagnan is led by the Captain of the Guards up the stairs to the execution platform. The executioner and the Priest wait patiently above. D'Artagnan sees the bloodstained block where his neck will soon lie; pales. The Priest mutters comfort: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 62   CONTINUED:                                                        62 PRIEST Fear not, my son... D'Artagnan regards the Priest whose face is hidden be- neath the brim of his broad black hat. He holds a large Bible in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For we are with you, always. The Priest raises his face, reveals it... and winks.         It is Aramis. He whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All for one, and one for all... D'Artagnan's heart soars. He turns to face the execu- tioner. Porthos grins beneath the hood's overhang.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prepare the prisoner. Porthos lays his axe aside, approaches d'Artagnan in a threatening manner. He takes him by the scruff of the neck, and forces his head upon the chopping block. The crowd goes wild.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, boy. You won't feel a thing. The Captain of the Guards gives Aramis a suspicious look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is Father Rostand today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The good father is... all tied up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well.   Proceed. Porthos nods. 63   ANOTHER ANGLE                                                     63 Meanwhile, on the perimeter of the square, two figures ride on horseback, they wear familiar cloaks. A CLOSER look reveals Queen Anne and Constance. They ride through the city, towards the countryside beyond. But their progress has led them here. Anne frowns at the spectacle. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 63   CONTINUED:                                                   63 ANNE Barbarism.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Men call it justice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you surprised? She replies   with contempt, reins her horse away from the square, the   crowd, the executioner's axe. But Constance freezes in   place, eyes wide. As d'Artagnan, upon the cart, rolls   INTO VIEW.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's him. For just a moment, their eyes lock. Inestimable space between. Constance's eyes fill with tears, she watches d'Artagnan. Porthos steps back from d'Artagnan, raises his axe. D'Artagnan shuts his eyes, wonders, mutters a silent prayer. That's when screams of panic erupt from the crowd. D'Artagnan raises his head to see the source of this mayhem. 64   MARKET SQUARE                                                64 The Cardinal's crimson carriage races toward the scaffold, scattering the crowd in all directions. Men shout, women scream, all leaping to avoid the stallion's sharp hooves, the coach's THUNDEROUS spinning WHEELS. In the driver's seat, clutching the reins in one hand and CRACKING a WHIP in the other... is Athos. Porthos uses the heavy blunt end of the axe to topple the closest men-at-arms. Aramis opens his Bible, pulls out a PISTOL, and BLASTS the saber from the hand of the Captain of the Guards. A man-at-arms raises his musket to shoot the false priest, but d'Artagnan leaps out of nowhere, lands on him with both feet, knocking the man- at-arms off the scaffold. 65   CARRIAGE                                                     65 Athos pulls up alongside the scaffold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, your carriage. Compliments of the Cardinal. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 65   CONTINUED:                                                     65 D'Artagnan rushes to the edge of the scaffold, springs into the air, landing on the seat beside him. Aramis and Porthos shed their disguises, jump after, light upon the carriage. The roof fabric tears, they drop into the plush interior below. Athos CRACKS the WHIP... and the stallions race off through the crowd, towards freedom. 66   SQUARE                                                         66 Constance watches the escape, transfixed, delighted. As the carriage barrels from the scaffold, she thrusts a gloved fist into the air, triumphant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! 67   TOWER                                                          67 But the Cardinal looks on with horror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My carriage. 68   CARRIAGE                                                       68 Athos produces a dagger, cuts the leather ties that bind d'Artagnan's wrists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on! Athos cracks the whip, driving the horses onward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 69   INT. CARRIAGE - DAY                                            69 Aramis and Porthos have settled in comfortably.      Porthos spies a wicker hamper on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, what have we here? Porthos lifts the lid. Inside: bottles of wine, champagne, and a wide assortment of foods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How considerate of the Cardinal to provide us with a snack. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 69   CONTINUED:                                                      69 Porthos extracts a bottle of wine, grabs a turkey leg. Aramis looks about the interior, spies a small ornate box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. Aramis opens the box, reacts.        It is filled with gold coins, jewelry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is it that a man of God becomes a man of gold?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trinkets for the ladies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's share. 70   STREETS OF PARIS - CARRIAGE                                     70 Aramis sticks his head through the hole in the fabric roof, hands the ornate box to d'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you be so good as to distribute these? Your generosity will be greatly appreciated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throw the coins, boy.     The people are hungry. D'Artagnan grabs a handful of coins, and tosses them into the air. Aramis smiles approval, drops back to the carriage interior. Pedestrians see the gold, shout, and leap after. Their hurried steps impede the Guards' pro- gress, horses rear up, soldiers tumble. But several of the Guards manage to avoid the obstacle, pursue the carriage with renewed determination. D'Artagnan hears a LOUD POPPING sound, ducks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're firing at us! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 70   CONTINUED:                                                    70 Porthos sticks his head INTO VIEW, offers them a bubbling bottle of champagne, the source of the popping sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Champagne?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I prefer wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't go away. Porthos ducks down, returns with a new bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I recommend this find Cabernet? Porthos hands   the bottle to Athos. Athos hands the reins to d'Artagnan.    D'Artagnan struggles with the reins, tries to control the   horses. And beams, taking delight from every instant   of adventure. Athos SMASHES the top of the BOTTLE, drinks   deeply, settles back to enjoy himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn right at the next street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The next right...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn. Athos growls, d'Artagnan jerks at the reins. The carriage careens around the corner, tipping on two wheels. 71   INCLUDE INTERIOR                                              71 Porthos looks up from his chest, champagne spilled all over his tunic... and a brand new sash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it. Next time, you drive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 72   EXT. STREET - DAY                                             72 The carriage charges up a steep hill. At the summit, Athos tosses aside his bottle, takes the reins from d'Artagnan. (CONTINUED) 61. 72   CONTINUED:                                                      72 D'Artagnan sighs with relief. Athos yanks the brake lever, brings the horses to a halt, and leaps down from the driver's seat. D'Artagnan follows. Athos pulls the passenger door open, revealing Porthos and Aramis inside. Gold coins on the carpet at their feet, food and drink between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, this is the end of the line. I hope you had a pleasant ride. (to d'Artagnan) Unhitch the horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the Guards. D'Artagnan points to the bottom of the hill.       The mounted Guards chase after, begin their ascent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do as I say. D'Artagnan hurries to the horses. Porthos and Aramis climb from the cab. Porthos emits a contented belch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your pistol and powder, please. Aramis hands Athos a sack of powder, and his pistol. Athos tosses the sack into the carriage, takes aim with the PISTOL, and SHOOTS it -- igniting the powder inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stand back. The interior of the Cardinal's carriage bursts into flames. 73   BOTTOM OF HILL                                                  73 D'Artagnan and the three Musketeers mount the Cardinal's white stallions, race off into the distance. Porthos shouts, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd give five years of your life just to see the Cardinal's face!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 62. 74   RICHELIEU'S FACE                                             74 The Cardinal's face is contorted in fury. He    steps out of a horse cart, approaches the charred remains   of his be- loved carriage. He stares at the smouldering    ruin for a long beat. Rochefort and a company of Guards    stand near- by, wait for him to speak. When he does, his    tone is measured and calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One thousand pistoles on each of their heads, dead or alive. The boy knows our plans. Rochefort reacts with surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't eaten in three days. I guess with all the excitement, I forgot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your trip from home has been an eventful one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard of a d'Artagnan once. He was a captain in the Musketeers when we were just recruits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A good man, I'm told.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew there was something familiar about this boy. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 75   CONTINUED:                                                      75 D'ARTAGNAN (sadly) He died when I was nine. The mention of the elder d'Artagnan's death casts a pall. D'Artagnan continues, tentative, the memory still hurts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All my mother would tell me is that he died in the service of the King. An uncomfortable silence.     It is Athos who finally speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan, your father and another Musketeer were ambushed and murdered outside the Louvre. D'Artagnan pales, stunned and silent.      He manages a broken whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This other Musketeer -- is he still alive? I'd like to talk to him. Athos shakes his head.     Porthos adds:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You already have. His name is the Count De Rochefort. D'Artagnan isn't listening. He stands suddenly, turns, and walks away. He doesn't want the Musketeers to see the tears forming in his eyes. Aramis shouts after:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 76   EXT. WOODS - DAY                                                76 D'Artagnan stands at a flowing stream, wipes the tears from his eyes. Aramis appears at his side, offers silent comfort, a hand on d'Artagnan's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I imagined his death a hundred time. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 76   CONTINUED:                                                        76 D'ARTAGNAN (CONT'D) On a battlefield, defending his King. Fighting bravely for France. And now... I will find the man who murdered my father and kill him where he stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man is better measured by his life than by his death. Your father was bold, and brave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you never knew him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lives in you. That's all the evidence Aramis requires.       D'Artagnan pauses to reflect. Then wonders:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And your father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was orphaned at a young age. The church took me in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't have one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I did. He was a great man, a leader of the church. And his example inspired me to dedicate my life to God's service. Aramis opens his cloak, reveals a priestly cloth.       A secret he carries near to his heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were a priest...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was a fool. (eyes on the cool water) This great man, this father, betrayed the church, and turned his back on God. To worship power and gold. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 76   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It broke my heart to see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you became a Musketeer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I joined the Musketeers and a strange thing happened. I got my faith back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But who was that man...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of France knows him. His Eminence, the Cardinal Richelieu. D'Artagnan nearly jumps from his boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 77   EXT. ROOF OF PALAIS CARDINAL - DAY                             77 Richelieu stands on the roof   of the Palais, lost in thought.  He looks down and   sees, through the smoke and mist, the silent rooftops of   Paris, pointed, innumerable. Richelieu turns, and crosses   to an elaborate pigeon coop. Servants attach messages to   the legs of carrier pigeons. Rochefort steps INTO VIEW, anxious, out of breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Eminence. The Musketeers have been sighted riding north on the road to Calais. Richelieu nods, he already knows.       He picks up one of the pigeons, strokes it gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry. Thanks to our winged friends, every mercenary and bounty hunter in France will be waiting for them. (with a smile) Isn't modern communication a wonderful thing? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 77   CONTINUED:                                                      77 Richelieu releases the bird, and watches it streak sky- ward, flying across the sky. CUT TO: 78   EXT. WOODS - DAY                                                78 The three Musketeers gather around d'Artagnan, listen to his story. In mid-telling:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I couldn't hear it clearly, I was standing by the door, the voices were low -- PORTHOS Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cardinal sent someone to England. With a secret treaty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's made an alliance with a man named, Bucking... Buckingham. The Musketeers look at each other with alarm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Duke of Buckingham?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rules England the way Richelieu rules France. D'ARTAGNANj A ship called the Persephone waits for the Cardinal's agent at Calais. To take him to England. Tuesday, midnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Calais is over two hundred leagues from here... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 78   CONTINUED:                                                    78 PORTHOS This messenger and the treaty will prove the Cardinal a traitor. If we can get our hands on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we waiting for, let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait. Athos stops their exuberant plots and plans with a single word. All turn, wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does the Cardinal know you have this information?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he knows we have it too. And he'll do everything in his power to stop us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But with three men trying, one of us might be able to make it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four. Bold words. D'Artagnan matures by leaps and bounds. Athos almost smiles. 79   EXT. ROAD TO CALAIS - NIGHT                                   79 Fog drifts across    a lonely stretch of road. Suddenly: pounding HOOFBEATS    come over the scene. MUSIC SWELLS. And galloping out    of the fog come d'Artagnan and the three Musketeers,    riding hell-for-leather. HOLD ON this heroic tableau for    a long beat. 80   EXT. BRIDGE ON ROAD TO CALAIS - NIGHT                         80 Four rough-looking MERCENARIES crouch on a low bridge spanning a shallow stream. They are armed with muskets and swords. The Mercenaries wait in the darkness, whisper eagerly among themselves. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 80   CONTINUED:                                                    80 One of them hisses for silence, all conversation ends. And the sound of HOOFBEATS is heard in the distance. Faint, but growing closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shoot low. We'll need their heads for identification. The Mercenaries raise their muskets, take aim. Right on cue, four horsemen come THUNDERING out of the mist. But just before they reach the bridge, the four horsemen break in half -- one pair rides to the left, the other to the right. Before the Mercenaries realize what's happened, the horsemen ride on either side, splashing through the shallow stream. In a flash, they return to the road, and race away. Having avoided the bridge completely. Cursing, the angry Mercenaries whirl about, FIRE at d'Artagnan and the three Musketeers as they ride into the night. Porthos' merry laugh drifts back to mock them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 81   EXT. ROAD TO CALAIS - NIGHT                                   81 An overturned wagon lies in the ditch. Beer kegs litter the roadway. The wagon's driver, an old FARMER, sits on one of the kegs, holding his head. D'Artagnan and the Musketeers gallop INTO VIEW, rein their horses to a stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank God for a friendly face. My horse broke loose. Can you help me move these kegs out of the road? D'Artagnan starts to dismount.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay on your horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He needs our help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry.   We'll help him. Suddenly: two other men step before the wagon, pointing muskets. The ragged Farmer reaches inside his coat, pulls out a pistol, makes a smirking request: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 81   CONTINUED:                                                   81 FARMER Won't you step down... Musketeers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, I beg you. Please put away your weapons and remove these kegs from the road. We'd prefer to ride on without having to kill you. D'Artagnan and the "Farmers" gape at Aramis in surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're threatening us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not a threat, it's a fact. If you don't haul those kegs away, you're dead where you stand. The Farmer laughs, contemptuously. He raises his pistol and aims it at Porthos' head. But before he can pull the trigger, THREE EXPLOSIONS ERUPT from under the cloaks of Athos, Porthos and Aramis. When the smoke clears, d'Artagnan is startled to see the three dead "Farmers" sprawled in the road and the three pistols emerging from beneath the cloaks of the Musketeers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine hit the ground first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine was taller. Aramis swings out of the saddle and begins to perform last rites over the bodies. D'Artagnan still can't be- lieve what just happened. He turns to Porthos. Porthos raises the barrel to his lips and blows away the gunsmoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's only one rule, d'Artagnan
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stay alive. THUNDER RUMBLES and RAINS begins to fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 82   CONTINUED:                                                     82 Present are the INNKEEPER, his wife, a few benighted tra- velers and THREE BARMAIDS. They turn as the door flies open and the Musketeers and d'Artagnan enter from a RAGING STORM. They keep their cloaks drawn about them and wear the brims of their hats pulled low to cover their faces. The occupants of the inn regard the new arrivals with suspicion. Outisde, the STORM BLOWS. D'Artagnan closes the heavy door. Fearful, the Innkeeper comes forward to meet the four ominous travelers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See to our horses and bring us some food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry but we have little to spare. The Cardinal's Guards were here today. They helped themselves to our food and then refused to pay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the name of God, I'm sure. Porthos is on the lookout for danger. He reaches inside his cloak for a weapon and, in doing so, accidentally exposes his Musketeer tunic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers! The sound of SLIDING STEEL as Athos, Porthos, Aramis and d'Artagnan draw their swords, ready to fight. They stand back to back in a circle, ready for attack. But there is no attack. Quite the contrary.       The people here are thrilled to see them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers in my house! Gentlemen, put away your swords and come in. Anyone who fights the Cardinal is welcome here. The Musketeers lower their swords. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 82   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we've found a home. The Musketeers return their swords to their sheathes and take off their dripping hats and capes. The pretty Barmaids crowd around them to collect their gear and car- ry it to the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't have much but what we have is yours. Porthos rubs his hands together, eager to indulge himself. He follows the Barmaids, booming in his loud, friendly voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ladies, you're in for a treat tonight. Allow me to introduce myself. I'm the Musketeer they call Porthos. Porthos beams, waiting for a big response but nothing happens. The Barmaids look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Porthos. Still no response.    Aramis and d'Artagnan hide smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hard to believe they haven't heard of the great Porthos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, shut up, Aramis. The three Barmaids perk up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aramis? Did you say Aramis? And with that, the three Barmaids desert Porthos and scurry across the room to attach themselves to Aramis. Porthos shakes his head and flops down in a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't get it. I just don't get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 72. 83   INT. TAVERN - NIGHT                                           83 Moments later.   Porthos regales the Barmaids with a tale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said, 'A Queen is no different than a barmaid in the dark. Though less... practiced in the arts of pleasure...' The Barmaids accept his leering compliment with glee. But d'Artagnan isn't so sure. Porthos, with two Barmaids, bellows a reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're going to be a proper Musketeer, you'll have to learn the manly art of wenching. Right, ladies? The Barmaids heartily concur. D'Artagnan looks over Porthos' shoulder, to the dark-haired Barmaid seen previ- ously. Porthos follows his gaze, grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ahh, very good. Your first subject. But you'll need instruction. Watch closely. Porthos pulls one of the Barmaids to his chest, brings her lips toward his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The secret to wenching is the first kiss. For in that kiss, a lasting impression is made. If it is weak, she will think you are weak. And if it is comical, she will think you are a clown. With me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Weak... weak.    Comical... clown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good.   And as a Musketeer is never weak,  and only rarely a clown, your  first kiss must be all the things  that you are. Like this... Porthos gives the Barmaid a powerful kiss.      He breaks it, turns to d'Artagnan with a grin. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 83   CONTINUED:                                                    83 PORTHOS You may speak first if you like, your name, her name, an endearment or two. But words are usually a waste of time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only if you don't know which words to say. All turn to regard Aramis. He'll play along too. Porthos reacts with delight. D'Artagnan with interest. Aramis continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Words may make a more lasting impression than a thousand of Porthos' kisses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not likely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll demonstrate. Please.   Sit beside me. Aramis' courtly behavior is as out of place in these en- virons as it is persuasive. The Barmaid slips from Porthos' lap, sits down on the bench beside him. Aramis does not touch her. He simply looks into her eyes... and begins to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? Thou art more lovely and more temperate: Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May, And summer's leash hath all too short a date; Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines, And often is his gold complexion dimmed; And every fair from fair sometimes declines, By chance, or nature's changing course untrimmed; But thy eternal summer shall not fade. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 83   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest, Nor shall death brag thou wanderest in his shade, When in eternal lines to time thou growest; So long as men can breathe, or eyes can see. So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.' The Barmaid, once skeptical, sits silently. Her face covered with tears. Aramis pauses, almost embarrassed by the outcome. He turns to d'Artagnan, cites:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shakespeare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's cheating. The Barmaid on his lap disagrees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's beautiful. D'Artagnan looks at the dark-haired Barmaid across the room. Porthos urges him on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, d'Artagnan. We haven't got all night. D'Artagnan steps forward. The dark-haired Barmaid sees him coming and smiles. D'Artagnan stands before her, hesitates, not sure where to start. Then, remembering as best he can:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? Thou are move lovely and more tempest, er, more tempered...' (beat) Ahh, to hell with it -- D'Artagnan takes the Barmaid into his arms, delivers a powerful kiss. As previously demonstrated. Porthos and Aramis smile proudly. The Barmaids cheer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy's a natural. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 83   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So little time, so much to learn. D'Artagnan drains his flagon, indicates Athos sitting at a table by himself, scowling, working on his third bottle of Burgundy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In all the years I've know him... I have never seen Athos smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is he sitting by himself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Athos takes his drinking seriously. Ignore him. He'll be his usual warm, charming self by morning. (calls out) Service! My lap is cold! A Barmaid scurries INTO   VIEW. Porthos grabs her by the waist, adds the Barmaid   to the one already sitting on his lap. The chair breaks    beneath them, and all three go sprawling on the floor,   laughing heartily. 84   ATHOS                                                         84 He remains lost in drink. D'Artagnan appears beside him. He hides his concern behind a cheerful attitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come join us. Athos pulls d'Artagnan down with a dark smile.     He fills his flagon for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fight like a Musketeer. Let's see if you can drink like one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll drink anything you put in front of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Famous last words. (raising his flagon) What shall we drink to? D'Artagnan notices the dark-haired Barmaid eyeing him across the room. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 84   CONTINUED:                                                    84 D'ARTAGNAN Love? The word nearly makes Athos grimace. He stares at d'Artagnan for a long beat, then beyond. As if to look into another time and place. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love. (beat) Would you like to hear a story, d'Artagnan? A love story? Athos' voice reveals unexpected vulnerability, the pain he keeps inside. D'Artagnan is fascinated, moved. He nearly whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Athos takes a long pull from the bottle of burgundy, wipes the blood red wine from his lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I once knew a man... one of the Counts of Berry. My native province. When the good Count was about your age, he fell in love with a visitor from Paris. A breathtaking girl of seventeen. She was more than beautiful, d'Artagnan. She was... intoxicating. And this man, the poor idiot, he married her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't that what people do when they fall in love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be quiet and listen. (beat) The Count took her to his castle and made her the first lady of the province. They were happy for a time, as happy as a man and a woman can be. Then one day, while riding in the woods, the girl was thrown from her horse, and knocked unconscious. The Count hurried to help her. Her dress was torn. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 84   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On her her arm, the woman wore a gold band in the shape of a serpent. It was the only article of clothing she refused to remove. The Count's curiosity got the best of him. He reached over and slid down the gold band. He saw something on her arm... something she'd kept hidden 'til then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fleur d'lis. She'd been branded... 85   ANOTHER ANGLE                                                    85 D'Artagnan reacts with shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Count's angel turned out to be a murderess who escaped the Executioner's blade. She swore that she loved him. Swore that she had changed. And if he would just keep her secret, they would live a long life together. Athos pauses, imagines that life.      The Count and his angel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the Count was young and he was stupid. He was tormented by the ridicule of his social class. And so he rejected her. For her lies and for her past. (beat) And turned her over to the authorities to be executed for the crime. Athos now turns his unflinching gaze on d'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you see... his heart did not agree.  The Count soon realized what she had meant to him. And what he had done. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 85   CONTINUED:                                                     85 ATHOS (CONT'D) That his... betrayal was far greater than her own. (beat) Soon after he foreswore the society that shaped him. Gave up his title. And was never seen again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He loved her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He killed her. It seemed like the same thing after a while. HOLD ON Athos for a long time.       As he gathers up his pain, and puts it back again. Athos SMASHES open another BOTTLE. But the story has made d'Artagnan quite sober and a little sick to his stomach. He refuses another drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.   More for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aramis -- play something with some blood in it! I feel like dancing! Aramis launches into something appropriate. Porthos and a Barmaid get up and begin a festive folk dance. Porthos is damned good. His joie de vivre is infectious and soon everyone in the inn is clapping and encouraging him. Every once in awhile, another WEAPON -- a dagger or something -- drops out of Porthos' clothing and hits the floor with a CLATTER. That's when Porthos, dancing with abandon, spins out of control, trips and falls on Athos' table, crushing it to the floor. Porthos lies in the wreckage, staring up. Athos, totally unperturbed, looks down and offers him the bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Care to dance, Athos?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only if I can lead. Porthos blinks in amazement at Athos' grim face, then breaks out laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aramis!   Athos made a joke!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 86   ANGLE                                                        86 The Innkeeper comes down the stairs wearing a nightshirt and a sleepy expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, gentlemen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were we making too much noise?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You told me to wake you at dawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's dawn. They turn in disbelief to the shuttered windows. Sure enough. Sunlight is peeking in through the cracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beautiful morning, eh, d'Artagnan? D'Artagnan is terribly hung-over from the night's carousing. He looks like he could puke at any moment. So that's exactly why Porthos shouts to him and says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know,   d'Artagnan, it's not a good idea   to travel on an empty stomach.    You really should have had a big   portion of those sheep's brains... D'Artagnan covers his mouth.    Porthos laughs good- naturedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My head feels like it's filled with the King's marching band. Would you please stop whistling? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 87   CONTINUED:                                                     87 PORTHOS Whistling?   I'm not whistling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well someone is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Barmaid's kiss left him dizzy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear it too. It sounds like...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A connon ball. Athos is cut off by an EAR-PIERCING WHISTLE as a CANNON BALL drops out of the sky and STRIKES the ground nearby, sending up a tremendous EXPLOSION.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate cannon balls. Another BALL EXPLODES into the ground in front of them. Their horses rear up in fear, threatening to dump them out of their saddles. As the Musketeers and d'Artagnan struggle to control their horses, they look back and see an old castle atop a distant hill. A group of men operate two rusted cannons, left over from some long-forgotten war. The Musketeers barely calm their horses, when another BALL comes SCREAMING their way, IMPACTING a few feet away. As dirt rains upon them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's your head now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm beginning to wish the Cardinal had chopped if off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay with us, and you just might get your wish. Athos spurs his horse across the field, d'Artagnan and the Musketeers follow. But they discover crude battle- ments in their path. Athos changes direction, sees six horsemen waiting for them in the near distance. He changes direction again, as the horsemen charge after. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 87   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Split in half! D'Artagnan rides with me! D'Artagnan nods, thrilled to go with Athos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll see you in Calais!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or hell! Athos and d'Artagnan take off in one direction, Porthos and Aramis in the other. The pursuing horsemen soon race INTO VIEW, break in half to give chase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 88   INT. QUEEN'S BATH - DAY                                         88 A room heavy with mist and steam. Behind a maze of gauze screens, we discover Anne reclining in a large tiled bath, Constance attending. Constance replenishes the bath with pitchers of hot water drawn from a boiling cauldron. In mid-conversation, as confidantes and friends:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But how, your Majesty? How can you tell if you're really in love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think about him all the time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And when he's around, do your knees feel as weak as water?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And when he looks at you, do you suddenly forget how to breathe? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 88   CONTINUED:                                                   88 CONSTANCE Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you're in love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am. Anne turns to Constance, soap and water swirl about her naked body. She wonders:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll never believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young man who rescued us from the bandit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young man on the scaffold?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. I don't believe it. A warm beat. Anne and Constance are friends as much as they are Queen and subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you in love, Your Majesty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What an impertinent question. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 88   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you? Anne pauses.    If only her life, her emotions, were as simple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My love... is a matter of state. It's complicated. A sad beat.    Constance teases:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think about him all the time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Queen, my mind touches on many subjects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do your knees feel as weak as water?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When he looks at you, do you forget how to breathe? A beat. And Anne is a girl of eighteen again, not Queen. Wistful, she replies:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope he will someday.   I hope I will too. HOLD ON Anne for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 89   INT. QUEEN'S BATH - DAY (LATER)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constance, have you seen my...? Anne stops short. Cardinal Richelieu waits for her in the dressing chamber, now bows, assumes a supplicant air. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 89   CONTINUED:                                                     89 RICHELIEU Your Majesty, forgive me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cardinal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need your help. And could not in good conscience wait another minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want my help?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On what matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your... husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your King. Richelieu allows the jest, remains silent, watchful. Anne resumes, chooses her words with care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. As Your Eminence has been kind enough to advise me... (nods assent) It's the least I can do. Richelieu reacts with quiet pleasure.    He steps closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am worried about the King's... happiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Huguenot rebellion, occupation in the Antilles and Cayenne. The coming war with France. These are not the usual hobbies of youth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 89   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now he wishes to postpone his birthday celebration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He feels it is not... appropriate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds as though he is concerned with more important matters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is exactly why we must celebrate. (off her look) To show the world that the King of France is strong enough to face any enemy on any field. To show France... that he is King. (beat) He will listen to you. If you will speak. Richelieu makes his case with forceful eloquence, seeming loyalty. Anne considers, replies, noncommittal:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will speak to him. Anne senses hidden agenda, intrigues below the surface. The conversation's conspiratorial tone begins to disturb her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, if you'll excuse me, I...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Anne nods, turns back toward the chambers.       Richelieu calls after.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Majesty? (off her look) Please understand that I do not underestimate the value of your assistance. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 89   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that I wish for you to consider -- in fact, to know -- all that you and I might accomplish. Together. (quietly, as if to justify) For France. Richelieu steps away, his red cape swirling behind him. Anne feels a chill, pulls her robe more tightly about her body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 90   EXT. LOUVRE (PARIS) - DAY                                       90 Infantry troops drill outside the King's palace, prac- ticing muskets and sabers. CUT TO: 91   INT. THRONE ROOM - DAY                                          91 Louis watches from a balcony. Richelieu appears, fresh from his encounter with the Queen. Louis looks up, greets him with displeasure. 92   INT. THRONE ROOM AND GREAT HALL                                 92 Louis watches from a balcony. Richelieu appears, fresh from his encounter with the Queen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to be late, Your Majesty, but I was wrestling with an important matter of state. Richelieu never allows the mask to slip. Even for an instant. Louis glances at the throne room, the increasing number of Cardinal's Guards on duty. They make him feel uncomfortable. Louis speaks with renewed determination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is it I don't see any of my Musketeers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid... that's impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 92   CONTINUED:                                                     92 RICHELIEU They have become outlaws. They are terrorizing the countryside, robbing and killing innocent people. Louis can't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There must be some mistake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No mistake. I have reports from the local constables involved. Richelieu, ever prepared, produces a sheaf of papers. No doubt counterfeit. But Louis has no way of knowing. He takes the papers into his hands, reacts with sadness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are better off disbanded. Louis turns back to the balcony, the soldiers marching below. His mood glum and lonely. He sighs, moves on to another matter of business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Eminence, I've been hearing some very troubling rumors about you. Richelieu nods, not the least bit concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are so many to choose from. Is it the one about my alleged alliance with Buckingham? Let's see if I remember it correctly. While the English attack from without, I'll undermine the throne from within -- depose you -- and become sovereign of France myself. That rumor, Your Majesty? Richelieu smiles, his face a mask of innocence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It does seem rather farfetched. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 92   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If there are any doubts of my loyalty, they'll be put to rest when we appear together at your birthday celebration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been thinking about that. A birthday celebration when we're on the brink of war...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your subjects are eager to celebrate the birth of their King at a time like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not so eager.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have an idea. Why don't you discuss the matter with your Queen? Louis looks up, wonders. As Richelieu draws him deeper into his spider's strategems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 93   EXT. FRENCH COUNTRYSIDE - DAY                                  93 Porthos and Aramis ride hard, look back over their shoulders. They crest the top of a bluff, rein their horses to a stop. They can afford to rest for a moment. Their pursuit is at least a mile behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My horse will not survive another league.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten, twenty at the most. Porthos looks into the near distance, manages a weary smile. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 93   CONTINUED:                                                        93 PORTHOS Here's just the thing.     A nice, relaxing boat ride. At the bottom of the hill: a crude ferry lands at the bank of a swift, choppy river. CUT TO: 94   EXT. RIVER AND FERRY LANDING - DAY                                94 The ferry is an open flatboat -- a wooden platform, about fifteen-by-twenty feet. It travels from one shore to the other by means of a ferry rope. Transport is slow, the trip to the other shore takes nearly five minutes. As Porthos and Aramis arrive, the flatboat is just re- turning, piloted by its FERRYMAN, a hunched and weather- beaten gnome. Four passengers wait to be carried across -- TWO GENTLEMAN CAVALIERS on horseback, and a country WOMAN and her child. As the flatboat enters its slip, the two Cavaliers urge their horses on board, rudely jostling the Woman and her child to the rear. The Ferryman, an experienced boot-licker, bows and scrapes to the Cavaliers, collects the coins they toss to his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A privilege to carry you on my humble boat... The Ferryman turns a greedy eye on the Woman and child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two pistoles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I only have one. Couldn't my child ride free? She's so small...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two pistoles. A courtly voice intervenes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put away your money, madame. You and your child will cross the river under our protection. For free. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 94   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody rides for free! Under your protection bloody well indeed! I'll teach you a thing or two about protection! Apple- cheeked young fools!! -- Just who do you think you are!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers. Two two Cavaliers react to the word. The Ferryman does, too -- into cringing, obedient servant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers? Well, why didn't you say so? Of course you'll ride for free. I insist on it. This way, pretty madame. My what a lovely little girl...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Porthos!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Aramis takes Porthos by the shoulder and turns him so he can see their pursuers pouring over the top of the hill on their horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We sail! And with that, Porthos takes the sharp edge of his boom- erang and brings it down on the dock rope. The rope splits and the ferryboat lurches away from the dock. 95   HILL AND SHORE                                             95 The pursuers charge down the hill and ride to the end of the dock but they're too late. Porthos and Aramis have gotten away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 96   FLATBOAT                                                   96 Porthos laughs and taunts the angry pursuers. Aramis ties scarves around the horses' eyes to blindfold them for the crossing. Then he turns around and sees what Aramis is already seeing -- the two Cavaliers watch them with keen interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're those Musketeers everyone's been looking for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Popularity has its price. The First Cavalier smiles, produces a flask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have some excellent brandy here. Would you gentlemen care to drink a toast with us to the Cardinal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd be happy to. Porthos produces a bottle from under his cloak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you'll drink one with us to the King.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the only King we recognize... is the Cardinal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are those who would call that treason.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happily, no such objections have been raised... here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right.   I'll object.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's see. You are, by your dress and by your manner, members of a bone-lazy class of servile ninnyhammers whose slavish allegiance to His Eminence the Cardinal is as that of a dog who likes nothing better than to sniff today where he has peed the day before. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 96   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Piss is piss, no matter what robes surround it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well said. I'm impressed. Ninnyhammers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was momentarily inspired. The Cavaliers are not amused. The first replies in measured tones, his lips white with fury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I reply?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By all means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better to be a dog in the service of a great master, than a beef- witted moron so dazzled by the throne that he does not see the true nature of the foolish boy who wobbles atop it. Which is to say, that most muddy-brained of all men... a Musketeer. The Cavaliers have already pulled out their swords. Porthos and Aramis now reach for their own. Porthos deadpans:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe there's something  about us that just pisses people  off. At least I'd like to think  so. It's too bad we can only kill  them once. 97   FIGHT                                                       97 The middle of a river on a rocking flatboat is not the best place for a duel. But the combatants make the most of it. Slipping, sliding, and falling. They attack with everything they've got. The Cavaliers are excellent swordsmen. And, as if that were not enough, the Musketeers have an additional disadvantage -- they must keep the Woman and child clear of the flashing blades. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 97   CONTINUED:                                                     97 Porthos drives his opponent about the flatboat with a devilish grin, chases him between -- and at one point, over -- blindfolded horses. Aramis duels with the expected artistry, gradually re- ducing his opponent to tatters. At one juncture, the child loses her footing, slides toward the low end of the flatboat, the deep river beyond. Aramis executes a neat sidestep, stops the child's desperate progress with one arm while continuing to do battle with the other. He returns child to Mother with a grin, continues. The two Cavaliers are soon vanquished, groaning on the flatboat deck. Porthos and Aramis meet at the middle, breathless. Porthos complains:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been called a lot of things in my time...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Porthos...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But beef-witted is a little more than I can stand, not to mention unfair...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Porthos...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Aramis indicates the opposite shore as the flatboat approaches it. There, waiting patiently, swords and muskets already drawn... is a patrol of Cardinal's Guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you swim?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   My horse can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That'll do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But...? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 97   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You go first and I'll watch your progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no.   Please. After you. Stalemate. Then, they can't help it, Aramis and Porthos grin. Life is an adventure, lived to the fullest. They count...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One, two -- three! And with that, as the Woman and child, the Ferryman look on, Aramis and Porthos guide their horses into the raging river. The Woman whispers after:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.   God speed. Porthos manages a wink as he floats into the distance. 98   ON SHORE                                                       98 The Cardinal's Guards react with anger and disbelief. 99   RIVER                                                          99 A wild ride down the ROARING RIVER. Porthos clinging to his horse for dear life. Aramis keeping an eye on his fellow Musketeer... and the deep rapids up ahead. Through twists and turns, walls of white water, huge boulders, and gyrating whirlpools... Aramis and Porthos finally reach a quiet pool, a leafy shore beyond. They lead their horses from the water, step toward dry land... and see yet another (or perhaps the same) patrol of Cardinal's Guards. Waiting, swords drawn, for their arrival. Porthos looks down at his latest sash -- destroyed like the others. Aramis draws his saber, mutters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A nice relaxing boat ride... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 99    CONTINUED:                                                      99 And with that, Aramis and Porthos charge towards the Guards. CUT TO: 100   EXT. DENSE FOREST - DAY                                         100 Cool, clear water. WIDEN to reveal d'Artagnan and Athos at a shallow pond, watering their horses. The forest around them is dark and primeval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think we've lost them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll catch up eventually. To the point, as always. D'Artagnan pauses to look at their beautiful surroundings, remembers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father used to hunt in a forest like this. He promised to take me on my tenth birthday. I don't know why he picked that year. Something about a boy becoming a man. I'd lay in bed at night and imagine it, just the two of us. But he died before I could go with him. Athos is unmoved, or so it would seem.       He replies with quiet cynicism:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. You have your boyhood wish at last. The dark forest. The thrill of the hunt. The nearness of death. Only d'Artagnan is the hunted, not the hunter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd be proud to die for my King.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted to save you from the life of a Musketeer. You don't have to go looking for experience, d'Artagnan. It'll find you soon enough. And when it does -- it will mark you forever. Athos rides into the forest.    D'Artagnan hurries to follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 96. 101   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                         101 Athos leads d'Artagnan through the forest. Sunbeams shoot down through thick branches like golden bars. A pastoral setting, almost peaceful. And then: THUNDERING HOOFBEATS. Athos and d'Artagnan turn in surprise, see SIX HORSEMEN CRASHING through the glade. 102   ANOTHER ANGLE                                             102 Athos and d'Artagnan GALLOP through the dense forest. The horesmen FIRE PISTOLS as they ride. A SHOT grazes d'Artagnan's shoulder, he staggers, retains his mount. Athos leads them up a hillside, a series of boulders at the top. The climb is fast and treacherous, GUNFIRE all around them. Athos' horse is struck by a bullet, stag- gers forward... and collapses just as they reach the crest. D'Artagnan leaps off his horse, takes cover with Athos behind the boulders. Athos takes aim, FIRES a SHOT, and kills one of the horsemen below. The others curse, leap from their mounts, seek cover. SHOTS WHIZ back and forth like angry hornets. Stalemate, but not for long. They are badly outnumbered. The horsemen creep slowly up the hillside, from tree to tree. Athos turns to d'Artagnan as he reloads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll hold them off for as long as I can. Go on without me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't leave you here. Not like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ride to Calais and stop the Cardinal's agent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Athos... I can't. Athos points his pistol at d'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go, or I'll kill you myself. A few days ago, d'Artagnan would have obeyed without question. Fearful, if nothing else. But not here, not now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A duel then. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 102   CONTINUED:                                                     102 ATHOS You're insane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We never finished the first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. I'll toss a coin. Tails I stay, heads you remain. Agreed? D'Artagnan nods. Athos FIRES off another SHOT. He produces a gold coin, flips, slams it between palm and hand. And looks between. 103   ATHOS AND HIS POV                                              103 Heads. D'Artagnan is to remain.       Athos looks up without missing a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tails.    I stay. Athos returns the coin to his doublet without giving d'Artagnan a chance to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But...? Athos reloads, FIRES below. D'Artagnan recognizes the kindness he has received. That Athos cannot fully express it. And that there is no use arguing with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least take my pistol. He gives it to Athos.      They clasp hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't let us down... Musketeer. There are tears in d'Artagnan's eyes.       He knows Athos hasn't got a chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll never forget you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go! Athos turns away, SHOOTS at another horseman.       D'Artagnan runs to his MOUNT, GALLOPS away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 104   D'ARTAGNAN                                                     104 He rides, straining to hear the sounds of GUNFIRE. As long as the SHOTS continue, he knows Athos is alive. Abruptly... the SHOTS CEASE. D'Artagnan swallows his heart, and rides. CUT TO: 105   EXT. ROAD TO CALAIS - NIGHT                                    105 A lonely stretch of road, illuminated by moonlight. A signpost announces: CALAI 15 LEAGUES. An exhausted HORSE CLOPS INTO VIEW, its rider half-conscious in the saddle. It is d'Artagnan. He can barely keep his eyes open. Suddenly, d'Artagnan passes out, tumbles from his saddle, and lands in the middle of the road. He opens his eyes once -- a sky filled with stars -- then closes them. We hear HORSES, and the CREAK of a CARRIAGE APPROACHING. The DRIVER brakes, and the horses are brought to a halt just short of trampling d'Artagnan. In the darkness, we can make out other shapes, rugged men on horseback, bodyguards to the carriage's passenger. Milady de Winter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, Henri?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a body in the road, Milady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be careful. Pistols are cocked.    Henri's shadow falls across d'Artagnan's body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a young man. He appears to be injured. We hear the CARRIAGE DOOR OPEN.     FOOTSTEPS to d'Artagnan's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My, what a handsome boy. Put him inside with me. Strong hands grasp d'Artagnan and lift him from the cold ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 99. 106   D'ARTAGNAN'S POV - BLACK SCREEN                             106 Out of the darkness, a face appears,   BLURRY and OBSCURED. It FILLS the SCREEN, slowly swimming   INTO FOCUS. It is Milady de Winter, even more beautiful   in CLOSEUP. Familiar, and no doubt deadly, ivory   combs gleam in her hair. She smiles warmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome back.    Did you dream? 107   ANOTHER ANGLE                                               107 reveals the interior of a bed chamber at a roadside inn. D'Artagnan, regaining his senses, finds himself propped up in a large bed. He blinks into the face of Milady who sits at the edge. His eyes widen with recognition, faint awe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have we met?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... saw you in Paris. D'Artagnan notices that his shoulder has been bandaged. He looks around the large room. A FIRE ROARS in the grate. Food and drink have been set upon a table. D'Artagnan continues, still groggy, uncertain:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where am I...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Calais.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Calais! (muttered; to self) The ship... Tuesday at midnight... D'Artagnan leaps out of bed. Then realizes he is stark naked. Milady smiles. D'Artagnan gathers a bedsheet around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are my clothes? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 107   CONTINUED:                                                       107 MILADY Filthy. I'm having them cleaned. Is something wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What day is it? What time?! D'Artagnan runs to a window, and throws open the shutters. Beyond: the harbor lights of the Port of Calais.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Tuesday, near nine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nine?   Are you sure? Somewhere in the night, a BELL TOLLS the HOUR.        Milady smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite sure. D'Artagnan relaxes slightly.        Milady rises from the bed. She wears a sky blue dressing       gown, something soft and silken beneath it. D'Artagnan        reacts perceptibly. En- joying his discomfort, Milady       crosses the room, joins him at the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you in a hurry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did I... get here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found you in the road. Discarded. Like an unwanted kitten. Do you have a name or shall I make one up for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is d'Artagnan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D'Artagnan. I like that. I am the Countess de Winter. Milady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My husband's dead. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 107   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have learned to live with death. She manages to combine sympathy, seduction, and just a hint of danger. All in a single reply. D'Artagnan hesitates, he is not immune to her charms, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess, I'm very grateful for what you've done, but I can't stay here. I've got...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Important business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How mysterious. A handsome young man with 'important business' in the still of night. Does it involve a young lady?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it require clothes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.   I need my clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They won't be ready for at least an hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An hour?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told the  innkeeper to bring them when they  are dry. Until then, I'm afraid  you are my prisoner. Would the  prisoner care for a drink? Milady crosses to the table, food and drink upon it. As she passes by the fire, her dressing gown seems to disap- pear, revealing a silhouette that makes d'Artagnan's heart stop. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 107   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am... thirsty. Milady pours wine into glasses, turns to face him.      And offers a smile that dazzles and burns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Then we will sit by the fire, and eat and drink, and you may impress, perhaps even move me, with the story of how you came to lie unconscious, in the middle of the night, on the road to Calais. (soft seductively) I love a good adventure. D'Artagnan hesitates, then steps to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 108   EXT. ROOF OF PALAIS CARDINAL (PARIS) - NIGHT                  108 A CARRIER PIGEON FLUTTERS out of the dark sky, and enters its box. The little door on the other side opens. A hand reaches in and removes the bird. Richelieu unpeels the message on its leg. CUT TO: 109   INT. CARDINAL'S PRIVATE CHAMBER - NIGHT                       109 A room as cold as the man who owns it. Behind Richelieu's desk, there is a life-sized portrait of the King. Rochefort occupies a window seat, cleaning d'Artagnan's sword. He lifts it to the light, and slashes the air. He stands, duels with an imaginary opponent. Richelieu enters with the message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wonderful thing about an imaginary opponent is that he is always greatly skilled, and always easily defeated. The pride of victory, without the risk of loss. If only life were like that. Richelieu sits at his desk, peers at the message.      He looks up, pleased. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 109   CONTINUED:                                                       109 RICHELIEU Milady has reached Calais.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you not to worry about the Musketeers. They are dead by now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buckingham's signature will be on the treaty by morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King's birthday celebration...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will proceed as planned. Thanks to the kind intercession of Queen Anne. Rochefort steps closer, speaks quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And our plans...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will proceed as well. Richelieu pours two glasses of port, offers one to Rochefort. They turn, raise their glasses to the King's portrait. And drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 110   INT. MILADY'S CHAMBER AT INN - NIGHT                      110 D'Artagnan and Milady face each other on a rug in front of the roaring fire. The plate of food between them is empty. They drink wine from goblets. D'Artagnan drains his cup, and stares into the burning embers. Milady speaks quietly, with seeming compassion:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are sad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was thinking about my friends. Milady knows when to speak, and when to listen. She looks at d'Artagnan with gentle expression, allows him to continue. The warm room, the wine, her kindness. All conspire to loosen his tongue. D'Artagnan speaks quietly, from the heart: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 110   CONTINUED:                                                     110 D'ARTAGNAN The three best friends a man could have. We were separated on our way to Calais. I'm afraid I'll never see them again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What brings you here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to tell you. But I can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Important business.' D'Artagnan nods. He wants to impress her. He wants her to know how brave he is. And Milady is well aware of it. She looks down, assumes a more vulnerable pose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. Men make bold plans in secret. And women wait... to mourn, or to celebrate the outcome. I know from experience, it's a lonely vigil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I can tell you is... I'm on a mission for the King.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've heard that one before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a young man. And young men are given to exaggeration. However, if you would like to entertain me with a story, I'm eager to hear it. And please, make it very brave, filled with handsome knights and beautiful ladies. I know, a dragon -- There is nothing a man is more loathe to experience than a woman who does not take him seriously. D'Artagnan acts accordingly, and reveals: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 110   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came to Calais to stop a spy from sailing to England.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A spy...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe you... (beat) Aren't you afraid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeers are not afraid of anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew it. I knew you were a Musketeer the moment I saw you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. (with sudden concern) But, d'Artagnan, if this spy was to find out you are here, your life could be in grave danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Musketeer is not afriad of danger.
direction.name: direction
